awd_titl_txt: Molecular-scale Breaking due to Repeated Loading in Molecular Shuttles
awd_abstract_narration:
The rate at which machines degrade with use has a large impact on their value. For example, modern cars last significantly longer than cars built only thirty years ago due to diligent research into failure modes and subsequent design improvements. Nanotechnology has progressed so that we can successfully build nanomachines such as 'molecular shuttles': nanoscale transport systems powered by biomolecular motors capable of delivering molecular cargo. The goal of this project is to advance our understanding of the degradation mechanisms limiting the lifetime of these molecular shuttles. The PIs research showed that 'mileage' matters - for every thousandth of an inch of distance moved, the molecular shuttle shrank a few nanometers in length. In this research project, the PIs will investigate if the course matters as well, and let the molecular shuttles travel through increasingly curvy microfabricated tracks which puts mechanical stress on their structure and should cause them to break at increasing frequencies. These experiments will improve understanding of degradation mechanisms for nanomachines in general, enable improvement of the design of our 'molecular shuttles', and may even provide insights into how biological nanomachines degrade and age. The project will integrate undergraduate researchers and high school students, and the new insights will be integrated into a new nanobiotechnology course. Outreach activities include lab activities and lectures as part of the 'Introduction to Nanotechnology' summer course for underrepresented high school students,

The project is guided by two hypotheses. Firstly, it is our hypothesis that breaking events will occur stochastically at average rates determined by mechanochemical principles. Secondly, it is our hypothesis that the overall degradation of molecular shuttles in engineered environments can be understood as a combination of breaking and shortening of the microtubule component. To test these hypotheses, we will observe microtubules moved by kinesin motors (our basic 'molecular shuttle') through microfabricated guiding structures which exert a defined amount of constant and cyclic strain on the microtubule. The outcome of the project will be a potentially transformational broadening of our perspective from the physics-inspired force spectroscopy of intermolecular bonds (measuring e.g. rupture forces) to an engineering-inspired view of an accumulation of damage as result of mechanical stress in nanomachines, which may ultimately result in fracture. More immediately, the results of the project will help the community to overcome the limited lifetime roadblock in the design of nanodevices based on biomolecular motors.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: The project resulted in the desired improved understanding in the degradation of nanodevices incorporating biomolecular motors and cytoskeletal filaments. The observed disappearance over time of microtubule/kinesin-based molecular shuttles is caused by a combination of microtubule shrinking, microtubule breaking and microtubule detachment. Microtubule detachment, that is the spontaneous unbinding of gliding microtubules from the propelling motors, is a newly identified degradation mechanism. This was an unexpected finding because it contradicts earlier theoretical predictions. More detailed analysis of microtubule breaking also yielded surprises: Gliding microtubules can survive sharp turns, but microtubules experiencing pinning at defective motors and bending simultaneously break easily. Therefore, microtubules which get stuck at defective motors account for the vast majority of the observed breaking events. Evidence that gliding microtubules experience materials fatigue was not found, which agrees with the recent discovery that microtubules can self-heal by replacing missing tubulin building blocks. Only extreme bending of stationary microtubules, conducted in collaboration with Japanese researchers, yielded signs of materials fatigue. This collaboration also yielded new insights into the control of swarms of molecular shuttles, and how the operation of the kinesin motors is affected by a curving microtubule. Our improved understanding of degradation suggests that it is possible to create a nanoscale "homeostatic" model system where the degradation of microtubules induced by the mechanical activity of kinesin motors is precisely balanced by repair processes.

Broader impacts: The obtained insights are valuable for the worldwide community of researchers working towards hybrid nanorobots incorporating synthetic and biological building blocks. We brought this community together by hosting the first Columbia "Molecules, Materials, Devices and Systems in Medicine" workshop in 2018, an event which resulted in new interactions, such as our collaboration with researchers from Hokkaido University. The insights were also incorporated into a redesigned class on the fundamentals of nanobiotechnology. The redesign advanced a new concept, where lectures and case studies are tightly integrated. The effectiveness of this teaching modality was thoroughly assessed and the results disseminated in the engineering education community, which received the work with great interest. Undergraduate and high school students were incorporated into the research activities throughout. The application of reflection interference microscopy to the imaging of our systems expands the technical toolbox of researchers in the field, and the obtained insights on microtubule mechanics will be of use to biophysicists and cell biologists.
